Snippets

This is a snippet example from an externalÂ file.

Over the Rainbow
as performed by Judy Garland
Somewhere over the rainbow
Way up high
Thereâ€™s a land that I heard of
Once in aÂ lullaby

Somewhere over the rainbow
Skies are blue
And the dreams that you dare to dream
Really do comeÂ true

Someday Iâ€™ll wish upon a star
And wake up where the clouds are far
Behind me
Where troubles melt like lemon drops
Away above the chimney tops
Thatâ€™s where youâ€™ll findÂ me

Somewhere over the rainbow
Bluebirds fly
Birds fly over the rainbow
Why then, oh why canâ€™tÂ I?

If happy little bluebirds fly
Beyond the rainbow
Why, oh why canâ€™tÂ I?

I am the Very Model of a Modern Major-General
Songwriters: W. S. Gilbert / ArthurÂ Sullivan

I am the very model of a modern Major-General,
Iâ€™ve information vegetable, animal, and mineral,
I know the kings of England, and I quote the fights historical,
From Marathon to Waterloo, in order categorical;
Iâ€™m very well acquainted too with matters mathematical,
I understand equations, both the simple and quadratical,
About binomial theorem Iâ€™m teeming with a lot oâ€™ newsâ€”
With many cheerful facts about the square of theÂ hypotenuse.

Iâ€™m very good at integral and differential calculus,
I know the scientific names of beings animalculous;
In short, in matters vegetable, animal, and mineral,
I am the very model of a modernÂ Major-General.

I know our mythic history, King Arthurâ€™s and Sir Caradocâ€™s,
I answer hard acrostics, Iâ€™ve a pretty taste for paradox,
I quote in elegiacs all the crimes of Heliogabalus,
In conics I can floor peculiarities parablous.
I can tell undoubted Raphaels from Gerard Dows and Zoffanies,
I know the croaking chorus from the Frogs of Aristophanes,
Then I can hum a fugue of which Iâ€™ve heard the musicâ€™s din afore,
And whistle all the airs from that infernal nonsenseÂ Pinafore.

Then I can write a washing bill in Balylonic cuneiform,
And tell you every detail of Caractacusâ€™s uniform;
In short, in matters vegetable, animal, and mineral,
I am the very model of a modernÂ Major-General.

In fact, when I know what is meant by â€œmamelonâ€ and â€œravelinâ€,
When I can tell at sight a chassepâ€t rifle from a javelin,
When such affairs as sorties and surprises Iâ€™m more wary at,
And when I know precisely what is meant by â€œcommissariatâ€,
When I have learnt what progress has been made in modern gunnery,
When I know more of tactics than a novice in a nunnery:
In short, when Iâ€™ve a smattering of elemental strategy,
Youâ€™ll say a better Major-General has never sat aÂ geeâ€”

For my military knowledge, though Iâ€™m plucky and adventury,
Has only been brought down to the beginning of the century;
But still in matters vegetable, animal, and mineral,
I am the very model of a modernÂ Major-General.

prevail!

Markdown Fig-capÂ Extension

entry.title: Feature Test 1 - PureÂ Markdown
entry.summary: This is a pure Markdown feature test. It test the JG version of Markdown.
entry.content:
Markdown:Â Syntax

Note: This document is itself written using Markdown; you
can see the source for it by adding â€˜.txtâ€™ to the URL.

Overview

Philosophy

Markdown is intended to be as easy-to-read and easy-to-write as isÂ feasible.

Readability, however, is emphasized above all else. A Markdown-formatted document should be publishable as-is, as plain text, without looking like itâ€™s been marked up with tags or formatting instructions. While Markdownâ€™s syntax has been influenced by several existing text-to-HTML filters â€“ including Setext, atx, Textile, reStructuredText, Grutatext, and EtText â€“ the single biggest source of inspiration for Markdownâ€™s syntax is the format of plain textÂ email.

BlockÂ Elements

Paragraphs and LineÂ Breaks

A paragraph is simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated by one or more blank lines. (A blank line is any line that looks like a blank line â€“ a line containing nothing but spaces or tabs is considered blank.) Normal paragraphs should not be indented with spaces orÂ tabs.

The implication of the â€œone or more consecutive lines of textâ€ rule is that Markdown supports â€œhard-wrappedâ€ text paragraphs. This differs significantly from most other text-to-HTML formatters (including Movable Typeâ€™s â€œConvert Line Breaksâ€ option) which translate every line break character in a paragraph into a <br> tag.

When you do want to insert a <br> break tag using Markdown, you end a line with two or more spaces, then typeÂ return.

Headers

Markdown supports two styles of headers, Setext and atx.

Optionally, you may â€œcloseâ€ atx-style headers. This is purely cosmetic â€“ you can use this if you think it looks better. The closing hashes donâ€™t even need to match the number of hashes used to open the header. (The number of opening hashes determines the headerÂ level.)

H1

H2

H3

H4

H5
H6

Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ishÂ style:

Alt-H1

Alt-H2

Blockquotes

Markdown uses email-style > characters for blockquoting. If youâ€™re familiar with quoting passages of text in an email message, then you know how to create a blockquote in Markdown. It looks best if you hard wrap the text and put a > before everyÂ line:

This is a blockquote with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus. Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae,Â risus.

Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit. Suspendisse id sem consectetuer libero luctusÂ adipiscing.

Markdown allows you to be lazy and only put the > before the first line of a hard-wrappedÂ paragraph:

This is a blockquote with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus.
Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae,Â risus.

Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit. Suspendisse
id sem consectetuer libero luctusÂ adipiscing.

Blockquotes can be nested (i.e. a blockquote-in-a-blockquote) by adding additional levels of >:

This is the first level ofÂ quoting.

This is nestedÂ blockquote.

Back to the firstÂ level.

Blockquotes can contain other Markdown elements, including headers, lists, and codeÂ blocks:

This is aÂ header.

They can do lists but it looksÂ goofy

  1. This is the first listÂ item.
  2. This is the second listÂ item.

Hereâ€™s some exampleÂ code:

return shell_exec("echo $input | $markdown_script");

Block quotes will work with citations ifÂ pushed

The secret to creativity is knowing how to hide your sources.

Attributed to Albert Einstein

Any decent text editor should make email-style quoting easy. For example, with BBEdit, you can make a selection and choose Increase Quote Level from the TextÂ menu.

Lists

Markdown supports ordered (numbered) and unordered (bulleted)Â lists.

Unordered lists use asterisks, pluses, and hyphens â€“ interchangably â€“ as listÂ markers:

  • Red
  • Green
  • Blue

is equivalentÂ to:

  • Red
  • Green
  • Blue

and:

  • Red
  • Green
  • Blue

Ordered lists use numbers followed byÂ periods:

  1. Bird
  2. McHale
  3. Parish

Itâ€™s important to note that the actual numbers you use to mark the list have no effect on the HTML output Markdown produces. The HTML Markdown produces from the above listÂ is:

  1. Bird
  2. McHale
  3. Parish

orÂ even:

  1. Bird
  2. McHale
  3. Parish

youâ€™d get the exact same HTML output. The point is, if you want to, you can use ordinal numbers in your ordered Markdown lists, so that the numbers in your source match the numbers in your published HTML. But if you want to be lazy, you donâ€™t have to. To make lists look nice, you can wrap items with hangingÂ indents:

  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus. Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae,Â risus.
  • Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit.Suspendisse id sem consectetuer libero luctusÂ adipiscing.

But if you want to be lazy, you donâ€™t haveÂ to:

  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus. Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae,Â risus.
  • Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit. Suspendisse id sem consectetuer libero luctusÂ adipiscing.

List items may consist of multiple paragraphs. Each subsequent paragraph in a list item must be indented by either 4 spaces or oneÂ tab:

  1. This is a list item with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus.
    Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet
    vitae, risus. Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum
    sit ametÂ velit.

  2. Suspendisse id sem consectetuer libero luctusÂ adipiscing.

It looks nice if you indent every line of the subsequent paragraphs, but here again, Markdown will allow you to beÂ lazy:

  • This is a list item with twoÂ paragraphs.

    This is the second paragraph in the list item. Youâ€™re only required to indent the first line. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscingÂ elit.

  • Another item in the sameÂ list.

To put a blockquote within a list item, the blockquoteâ€™s > delimiters need to beÂ indented:

  • A list item with aÂ blockquote:

    This is a blockquote
    inside a listÂ item.

To put a code block within a list item, the code block needs to be indented twice â€“ 8 spaces or twoÂ tabs:

  • A list item with a code block:
    <code goes here>

CodeÂ Blocks

Pre-formatted code blocks are used for writing about programming or markup source code. Rather than forming normal paragraphs, the lines of a code block are interpreted literally. Markdown wraps a code block in both <pre> and <code> tags.

To produce a code block in Markdown, simply indent every line of the block by at least 4 spaces or 1Â tab.

This is a normalÂ paragraph:

This is a code block.

Here is an example ofÂ python:

if pwd == 'apple':
    print('Logging on ...')
else:
    print('Incorrect password.')

print('All done!')

A code block continues until it reaches a line that is not indented (or the end of theÂ article).

Within a code block, ampersands (&) and angle brackets (< and >) are automatically converted into HTML entities. This makes it very easy to include example HTML source code using Markdown â€“ just paste it and indent it, and Markdown will handle the hassle of encoding the ampersands and angle brackets. For example,Â this:

<div class="footer">
    © 2004 Foo Corporation
</div>

Regular Markdown syntax is not processed within code blocks. E.g., asterisks are just literal asterisks within a code block. This means itâ€™s also easy to use Markdown to write about Markdownâ€™s ownÂ syntax. 

# H1
## H2
### H3
#### H4
##### H5
###### H6

Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ish style:

Alt-H1
======

Alt-H2
------

SpanÂ Elements

Links

Markdown supports two style of links: inline and reference.

In both styles, the link text is delimited by [squareÂ brackets].

To create an inline link, use a set of regular parentheses immediately after the link textâ€™s closing square bracket. Inside the parentheses, put the URL where you want the link to point, along with an optional title for the link, surrounded in quotes. ForÂ example:

This is an example inlineÂ link.

This link has no titleÂ attribute.

Emphasis

Markdown treats asterisks (*) and underscores (_) as indicators of emphasis. Text wrapped with one * or _ will be wrapped with an HTML <em> tag; double *â€˜s or _â€˜s will be wrapped with an HTML <strong> tag. E.g., thisÂ input:

singleÂ asterisks

singleÂ underscores

doubleÂ asterisks

doubleÂ underscores

HorizontalÂ Rule

Three orÂ moreâ€¦

Hyphens

Asterisks

Underscores

Code

To indicate a span of code, wrap it with backtick quotes (`). Unlike a pre-formatted code block, a code span indicates code within a normal paragraph. ForÂ example:

Use the printf() function.

Links

Iâ€™m an inline-styleÂ link

Iâ€™m an inline-style link withÂ title

Iâ€™m a reference-styleÂ link

Iâ€™m a relative reference to a repositoryÂ file

You can use numbers for reference-style linkÂ definitions

Or leave it empty and use the link text itself.

URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. http://www.example.com or http://www.example.com and sometimes example.com (but not on Github, forÂ example).

Some text to show that the reference links can followÂ later.

Photos

Hereâ€™s our logo (hover to see the titleÂ text):

Inline-style:

Reference-style:

Local Photos

entry.title: Americaâ€™s Test Kitchenâ€™s HummingbirdÂ Cake
entry.summary: A review of America’s Test Kitchen’s Hummingbird cake. A moist and sweet southern tradition.
